paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Can intratumoral mRNA vaccination increase tumor immunogenicity and improve response to anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint blockade in mice and in retrospective human ICI-treated patients?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Preclinical mice with tumor-bearing models receiving the combination therapy arm across pooled repeat experiments.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Matched preclinical controls (vaccine only, ICI only, and vehicle), pooled across repeat mouse experiments.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI, stratified by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective vaccinated subgroup within the human cohort used for survival comparison versus unvaccinated patients.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective unvaccinated comparator subgroup within the same ICI-treated metastatic patient cohort.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients in the retrospective human cohort.
Tumor-type mix and prior treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation of outcomes.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.
